entry.title: 100% M
entry.summary: Having had a web site for about 15 years, I start to wonder why I keep it in the first place.

a.title: 100% M by Sigfrid Lundberg, on Flickr

p.small: Figure 1. Some of my current photographic equipment. All of it is Leica M-mount. None of it is from Leitz/Leica.

div.p: Since November last year I've been shooting M mount (See Figure 1). There is, however, no real Leica stuff. I could possibly afford the real thing but then I would have to sacrifice a lot from the other parts in my life to get a marginal improvement of my kit.

The Leica brand is so strong that many buy cameras that are look alike or work alies. I too suffers from Leica envy inasmuch, but limit myself to admiring the lenses. I'm no longer interested in rangefinder technology. Among other things because I still have some really nice old Nikon lenses.

Instead the I have acquired the Ricoh GXR Mount A12, also known as GXR-M. That camera has some advantages. It is M mount, i.e., I can use lenses for the Leica mount without adapter. Then, it is optimized for use together with manual lenses. For instance, Ashwin Rao describes how he is able to do manual focus fast enough for sports photography. That impressed me, and it was one of the factors that settled the issue for me. Indeed, the focus peaking methods have become even more important for me since my eye sight has deteriorated since I ordered it.
Then, it has really good image quality. Sean Reid was the one who convinced me that anti-aliasing filters are detrimental for image quality.
Finally, the user interface is very well thought out. See Luminous Landscape's The field report.

I've presented most of my the lenses here and on Flickr before. On Figure 1 you can see Heliar 15mm f/4.5, 25mm f/2.8 ZM-Biogon and M-Rokkor 40mm f/2 which is mounted on the GXR-M body. On Figure 2 you see the body and a F mount and one M mount lens. Also, the the Nikon F to Leica M adapter is there.
